constants: Speed of light in a vacuum (c)
discoveries: The discovery of the electron by J.J. Thomson in 1897
The development of quantum mechanics in the early 20th century
Einstein's theory of relativity in 1905 and 1915
The discovery of the Higgs boson in 2012
The observation of gravitational waves in 2015
hypotheses: The speed of light in a vacuum is constant and does not depend on the motion of the source or observer.
Increasing the temperature of a ferromagnetic material above its Curie point will cause it to lose its magnetic properties.
The universe is expanding at an accelerating rate due to an unknown form of energy, called dark energy.
The position and velocity of a particle cannot both be precisely measured at the same time, as stipulated by the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle.
Entangled particles remain connected so that the state of one (regardless of distance) instantly affects the state of the other.
problems: The unification of general relativity and quantum mechanics
The nature of dark matter and dark energy
The origin of the universe and the Big Bang singularity
The hierarchy problem in particle physics
proofs: Proof of the conservation of energy
Proof of the conservation of momentum
Proof of Newton's second law from the action principle
Proof of Maxwell's equations from Gauss's and Faraday's laws
Proof of the equivalence of mass and energy (E=mc^2)
algorithms: Finite Difference Method for solving differential equations
Monte Carlo simulations for statistical physics
Fast Fourier Transform for analyzing waveforms
Molecular Dynamics simulations for studying atomic interactions
Density Functional Theory for electronic structure calculations
